ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to better write analytical essays.
Learned a lot about the spread of misinformation and the style associated with conspiratorial writing. We also talked a lot about good writing style in genereal.
How to write a college essay, analyzing and evaluating different texts and writing styles, etc.
We developed our skills at writing short papers as well as a longer research paper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really loved the course, definitely very interesting. I'm not sure how much of my writing improved because of this course specifically. We talked a little about good style and form for writing but I think it was mainly just more practice. I really enjoyed the discussions that we had in class and because of the small size, it was a very comfortable environment to speak up.

Strengths: the essay prompts were always fun to write, often left room for creative expression; the professor was kind, patient, and cared about individual growth and understanding; the readings were usually pretty interesting and never too overwhelming page-count-wise; the class discussions always felt open and straightforward and relatively informal, which made participation less intimidating; the opportunities to workshop each others' rough drafts of essays in class were really helpful and rewarding.

Weaknesses: the different readings sometimes felt random without a purposeful direction for the material observed over the course of the semester
The material on conspiracy theories is quite engaging, but some of the writing texts seemed pretty irrelevant.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We did breakout rooms but I think our class size was small enough for us to just have a discussion section for the entire class

The use of Zoom breakout rooms for essay workshops were extremely effectively and the different student-led (virtual) presentations throughout the course of the semester were fun and engaging, but the Perusall annotation assignments were sometimes unnecessarily taxing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It's a great introduction to college essay writing in a low-pressure environment, with topics that are genuinely interesting to learn about and a professor that will be really patient and encouraging with you and your writing. The workload is completely manageable, and the seminar-style makes for really fun discussions and a warm atmosphere that you can look forward to every day.
Yes. A great way to fill your writing credit. Readings were not too long, material is engaging, and there are only 4 papers.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
